history.content:
Since you're considering grad classes, I'd recommend you take CS 270 instead of 174. It covers a lot of the same material on randomized algorithms, at a much faster pace. 

---

I took 276 with Alessandro Chiesa in Fa15. Haven't taken 116 but I've skimmed over the textbook.

The classes really cover two different areas of cryptography. 276 mostly is concerned with algorithmically designing cryptographic tools from primitives that you just assume you have, e.g. weak one-way functions -> strong one-way functions -> pseudorandom generators/functions -> private-key crypto. It does not cover lattices, elliptic curves, or number theoretic aspects of cryptography (the math that lets us say "why is this candidate construction a good cryptographic primitive?") - 116 goes into some or all of these.

172 probably won't affect your ability to take either class to any appreciable degree. Neither of the crypto classes use computability theory (first half of 172) and the complexity bits of 276 are pretty self-contained.
Since you're considering grad classes, I'd recommend you take CS 270 instead of 174. It covers a lot of the same material on randomized algorithms, at a much faster pace.

children.subject:
172 would probably help a bit, but it's by no means necessary for 276. There's a bit of complexity theory in 276 - the most important parts are understanding what BPP, RP, and co-RP are, but they should be explained in 276.

Also 276 was an amazing class, you should definitely take it.
Allan, thank you for your response. I didn't mean cs 174, I meant cs 172 (Computability and Complexity). Some have said you should take cs 172 before cs 276.

276; I also took 276 in Fa15. The reasoning for this is that if you want to become a full-fledged researcher (e.g. knowing concepts that pops up all the time in crypto conferences), 276 is the mainstream answer. Math 116 is a very particular class that covers popularly known cryptographic primitives, but won't give you more of an "independent ability".

276 is analogous to a history class that provides analysis and concepts on why certain events occur (like wars), whereas 116 is like a history class that will provide mostly interesting facts.
Which course (116 or 276) would you say is more useful? Which is more interesting?

history.content:
Both are titled "Cryptography". I am a freshman and have taken CS 70 and 170 as well as Math 53/54. I am more interested in the cs aspect of cryptography, at first glance, but honestly I have no idea which aspect (cs or math) of cryptography is more important to learn.

Also, I haven't taken CS 174 CS 172 which I heard might be important to cs 276. What would you suggest to me? Thank you for the help!
history.subject: Math 116 vs CS 276?
